member.summary: Indicates the peer maps using table.

summary.para:
Indicates all maps that forms the each intersection. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
In addition, in this data structure, "CoverSet" is a block and "BaseSet" is a line.

member.summary: Indicates the mask of column that all cells in this collection spanned.

member.remarks: When the covered region can't be found, it'll return (i.e. 32) always.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.Count
member.summary: Indicates the total number of cells where the corresponding value are set .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.CoveredRegions
member.summary: Indicates all regions covered. This property is used to check all regions that all cells of this instance covered. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the region 0 (block 1) and region 9 (row 1); however, if cells spanned two regions or more (e.g. cells { 0, 1, 27 }), this property won't contain any regions.
member.remarks: The return value will be an value indicating each regions. Bits set 1 are covered regions.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.Regions
member.summary: All regions that the map spanned. This property is used to check all regions that all cells of this instance spanned. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the region 0 (block 1), region 9 (row 1), region 18 (column 1) and the region 19 (column 2).

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.Cells.op_Multiply(Sudoku.Data.Cells@,Sudoku.Data.Cells@)

summary.para: Simply calls -(a & b) & b. The operator is used for searching and checking eliminations.

The expression should be comprehended as those multiple steps:
a & b: Gets the intersection of two maps.
-(a & b): Gets the peer intersection of the result map in the step 1.
-(a & b) & b: Gets the cells in the step 2, which is included in the map b.
Returns the map in the step 3.

member.param: The limit map that the base map sees.

member.summary: Reverse status for all cells, which means all bits will be set , and all bits will be set .
member.remarks: While reversing the higher 40 bits, the unused bits will be fixed and never be modified the state, that is why using the code "higherBits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFL".

summary.para: Indicates the output should be with candidates. If the output is single line, the candidates will indicate the candidates-have-eliminated before the current grid status; if the output is multi-line, the candidates will indicate the real candidate at the current grid status.

If the output is single line, the output will append the candidates value at the tail of the string in ':candidate list'. In addition, candidates will be represented as 'digit', 'row offset' and 'column offset' in order.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Data.GridFormattingOptions.TreatValueAsGiven
member.summary: Indicates the output will treat modifiable values as given ones. If the output is single line, the output will remove all plus marks '+'. If the output is multi-line, the output will use '<digit>' instead of '*digit*'.

summary.para: Indicates the susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
Indicates the pencil marked grid (PM grid), which means all grid candidates will be displayed using a table.
Indicates the table format, which means all grid values will be displayed using a table with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
Sudoku explainer format (9 characters in a row, and 9 rows).
Sukaku sudoku format (only contains the digits and the whitespace).
Sukaku single line format, which uses '0' to be a placeholder.
Excel sudoku format (only contains the digits and the tab character).

For example:
1 7 8 9 4 5 6 4 5 6 1 2 3 7 8 9 7 8 9 4 5 6 1 2 9 1 2 6 8 3 4 3 4 5 6 7 8 7 8 3 5 9 1 2 9 1 5 6 7 2 3 4 2 3 4 8 9 1 5 6 7 5 6 7 2 3 4 1
(Due to the rendering engine of IDE, all spaces will be displayed only once in this table.)

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.SudokuGrid.ValuesMap

summary.para: Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of that value of each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.
Different with , the value only contains the given or modifiable cells whose mask contain the set bit of that digit.

member.remarks: Note that this property isn't a promptly one because the value won't be calculated until this property called.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.SudokuGrid.Exists(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the digit in the specified cell.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell is an empty cell and contains the specified digit.
The cell is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit.
The cell is not an empty cell.
member.remarks: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(candidate) is true' or 'grid.Exists(candidate) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.

member.summary: Get the candidate mask part of the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

returns.para:
The candidate mask. The return value is a 9-bit value, where each bit will be:
0 The cell doesn't contain the possibility of the digit.
1 The cell contains the possibility of the digit.
For example, if the result mask is 266 (i.e. 0b100_001_010 in binary), the value will indicate the cell contains the digit 2, 4 and 9.

summary.para: Parses a string value and converts to this type.

If you want to parse a PM grid, you should decide the mode to parse. If you use compatible mode to parse, all single values will be treated as given values; otherwise, recommended mode, which uses '<d>' or '*d*' to represent a value be a given or modifiable one. The decision will be indicated and passed by the second parameter .

summary.para: Indicates the output should be with candidates. If the output is single line, the candidates will indicate the candidates-have-eliminated before the current grid status; if the output is multi-line, the candidates will indicate the real candidate at the current grid status.

If the output is single line, the output will append the candidates value at the tail of the string in ':candidate list'. In addition, candidates will be represented as 'digit', 'row offset' and 'column offset' in order.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Resources.TextResources.Current
member.summary: Indicates the singleton to get items and method invokes.

remarks.para:
This is a instance, which means you can get anything you want using the following code style to get the items in this class:
Current.PropertyName (Property invokes)
Current[PropertyIndex] (Indexer invokes)
Current.MethodName(Parameters) (Method invokes)

For example, if you want to get the value from the key "Bug", now you may write Current.Bug or Current["Bug"] to get that value. Before the version 0.3, you must write the code TextResources.GetValue("Bug").

All supported methods are:
Current.Serialize(string instanceNameToSerialize, string toPath)
Current.Deserialize(string instanceNameToDeserialize, string fromPath)
Current.ChangeLanguage(CountryCode countryCode)
